Unless speciﬁcally stated otherwise, this IRM is written to provide structions to EP agents who discover an issue during a Form
examination that could potentially disqualify the plan. Plan qualiﬁcation issues (IRC
(a) failures) discovered through a Form examination can be resolved through: a. EPCRS b. A DO
closing agreement c. The unagreed case process Most qualiﬁcation issues discovered on EP examinations are resolved EPCRS. EPCRS guidelines are covered in IRM
, EPCRS Agreements and Rev. Proc.
When qualiﬁcation issues can’t be resolved through EPCRS, they will be: a. Resolved through a DO
closing agreement, or b. Processed as an unagreed case.

qualiﬁcation, discuss the issue with your group manager before formally advising the taxpayer that the IRS is proposing disqualiﬁcation of the plan.

This preliminary RAR should satisfy parts “a” through “d” of the ﬁnal RAR, but should be clearly notated as a “Draft” or “Preliminary” copy. See IRM
, Revenue Agent Report. The preliminary RAR is important for two reasons:
) It’s written docu- mentation that the IRS clearly discussed (and cited adequate authority) speciﬁc issues with the taxpayer.

) It places the document in the admin- istrative record for declaratory judgment purposes. Mail the preliminary RAR with an individually designed cover letter to the taxpayer and give them sufficient time to provide a response before you close the case unagreed to Mandatory Review.
Note: Mandatory Review will mail out the ﬁnal RAR with the 30-Day Letter (Letter 1756). See IRM 4.71.3.6.2, 30-Day Letter Package.
4.71.3.4.1 (12-04-2018) Tax Effect of Plan Revocation/Non- Qualiﬁcation
Disqualiﬁcation of a plan in any given year causes the plan to be disqualiﬁed in that year and in all subsequent years.

In general, once a plan is disqualiﬁed, it remains non-qualiﬁed until the qualiﬁcation issue(s) is corrected and the plan is re-qualiﬁed through a closing agreement. A plan may be disqualiﬁed in a year for which the Form

statute has already expired. Although tax cannot be assessed in a year, the consequences of disqualiﬁcation continue for all subsequent years and IRS can assess tax in subsequent years for which the statute is still open. The IRS’s ability to pursue a qualiﬁcation issue in any year is not impacted by the Form
statute of limitations. The expiration of the statute of limitations for Form
for any given year does not prevent
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
the IRS from pursuing a qualiﬁcation issue in that year (see Yarish Con- sulting, Inc. v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo 2010-174).
The tax effect of revocation/non-qualiﬁcation includes the following:
a. Realized earnings of trust assets are taxable each year the plan is not qualiﬁed (if the assessment of tax is not barred by statute). Trust earnings must be reported on Form
, which the trustee must ﬁle annually, on a calendar year basis. b. Per IRC

c. Law– The law section is where the authority for the qualiﬁcation issue(s) is cited. An agent can cite the following sources that relate to the raised as authority for the government’s position: the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), Temporary and Final Regulations, Revenue Rulings, Revenue Procedures, Court Decisions and Congressional Committee Reports. Note: Proposed Regulations can be referenced for interpretive purposes but cannot be cited as authority. Do not cite General Counsel Memos (GCMs), Private Letter Rulings (PLRs), or the Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) as sources of authority in the RAR. d. Government’s Position– This section should discuss each issue sepa- rately and apply the law and the facts relevant to each speciﬁc issue. This section should also indicate the date on which the plan failed to qualify. An explanation of why EPCRS was not used must be provided. This section should be concluded by clearly stating the government’s position. e. Taxpayer’s Position– This section should reﬂect the taxpayer’s position including any rebuttals the taxpayer has made regarding the govern- ment’s position. If the taxpayer has not provided a position on the issue(s), a simple statement to the effect that the taxpayer has not provided a response is sufficient. f. Rebuttal/Conclusion– If the taxpayer provides a position on the issue(s) during the examination or in response to the draft RAR, the RAR should contain a rebuttal to the taxpayer’s position when the case is closed to Mandatory Review. The government’s position should be restated as a conclusion in all cases. (

The administrative record will be used in Tax Court if the taxpayer ﬁles petition to go to court (in response to the
-Day Letter issued by Mandatory Review). Generally, the Court will decide a declaratory judgment solely on the basis of the administrative record.
